quiz.title: Unit 3: Demand and Supply (Quiz 3)
quiz.subtitle: 3.3 Determinants of Demand: Factors Shifting Demand Curves (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Demand Shifters, Non-Price Determinants, Changes in Demand vs Quantity Demanded

questions.question: Which of the following would cause the entire demand curve for coffee to shift to the right?
options: A decrease in the price of coffee
An increase in the price of coffee
An increase in consumer income (coffee is a normal good)
A decrease in the price of tea
questions.explanation: An increase in consumer income shifts the demand curve for normal goods to the right. A change in coffee's own price causes movement along the curve, not a shift.

questions.question: If coffee and tea are substitutes, an increase in the price of tea will:
options: Shift the demand curve for coffee to the left
Shift the demand curve for coffee to the right
Cause movement along the coffee demand curve
Not affect the coffee demand curve
questions.explanation: When the price of a substitute good rises, consumers switch to the alternative, increasing demand for the substitute and shifting its demand curve to the right.

questions.question: Which factor is NOT a determinant of demand that would shift the demand curve?
questions.explanation: The good's own price causes movement along the demand curve. The other factors are demand shifters that move the entire curve.

questions.question: If smartphones and data plans are complements, an increase in the price of data plans will:
options: Shift the demand curve for smartphones to the right
Shift the demand curve for smartphones to the left
Cause movement along the smartphone demand curve
questions.explanation: When the price of a complement rises, demand for both related goods decreases because they are consumed together, shifting the demand curve to the left.

questions.question: For inferior goods, an increase in consumer income will:
options: Shift the demand curve to the right
Shift the demand curve to the left
questions.explanation: Inferior goods are those for which demand decreases when income rises, as consumers switch to higher-quality alternatives, shifting the demand curve to the left.

questions.question: If consumers expect the price of cars to increase significantly next month, current demand for cars will:
questions.explanation: Expectations of future price increases encourage consumers to buy now rather than later, increasing current demand and shifting the demand curve to the right.

questions.question: A successful advertising campaign that increases consumer preference for a product will:
options: Shift the demand curve to the left
Shift the demand curve to the right
Cause movement along the demand curve
questions.explanation: Increased consumer preference means people are willing to buy more at each price level, shifting the demand curve to the right.

questions.question: If the number of buyers in a market increases, the market demand curve will:
questions.explanation: More buyers means more potential purchases at each price level, increasing overall market demand and shifting the demand curve to the right.

questions.question: Which scenario would cause the demand curve for winter coats to shift to the left?
options: A decrease in the price of sweaters (substitutes)
questions.explanation: A decrease in the price of substitutes makes alternatives more attractive, reducing demand for winter coats and shifting the demand curve to the left.

questions.question: If a product becomes more fashionable and popular among consumers, the demand curve will:
questions.explanation: Increased popularity and fashionability increase consumer preference, leading to greater demand at each price and shifting the demand curve to the right.

questions.question: The difference between a 'change in demand' and a 'change in quantity demanded' is that:
options: A change in demand involves movement along the curve, while a change in quantity demanded shifts the curve
A change in demand shifts the curve, while a change in quantity demanded involves movement along the curve
Both terms mean the same thing
Only quantity demanded can change, demand is always fixed
questions.explanation: A change in demand refers to a shift of the entire demand curve due to non-price factors. A change in quantity demanded refers to movement along the curve due to price changes.

questions.question: If the government announces a future tax increase on tobacco products, current demand for tobacco will likely:
questions.explanation: Expectations of future price increases (due to taxes) encourage consumers to buy now rather than later, increasing current demand and shifting the demand curve to the right.

questions.question: For luxury goods, a decrease in consumer income will:
options: Shift the demand curve to the right
Shift the demand curve to the left
questions.explanation: Luxury goods are normal goods with high income elasticity. A decrease in income reduces demand for luxury goods, shifting the demand curve to the left.

questions.question: If peanut butter and jelly are complements, and the price of jelly decreases, the demand for peanut butter will:
questions.explanation: When the price of a complement decreases, demand for both related goods increases because they are consumed together, shifting the demand curve to the right.

questions.question: A demographic shift that increases the elderly population would likely shift the demand curve for healthcare services to the:
questions.explanation: An aging population increases the number of consumers who need healthcare services, increasing demand and shifting the demand curve to the right.

questions.question: If consumer tastes shift away from sugary drinks toward healthier options, the demand curve for sugary drinks will:
questions.explanation: Decreased consumer preference means people are willing to buy less at each price level, reducing demand and shifting the demand curve to the left.

questions.question: Which of the following would NOT shift the demand curve for automobiles?
options: A change in the price of automobiles
A change in the price of gasoline
A change in consumer preferences for different vehicle types
questions.explanation: A change in the good's own price causes movement along the demand curve. The other factors are demand shifters that move the entire curve.

questions.question: If a product receives negative publicity that reduces consumer confidence, the demand curve will:
questions.explanation: Negative publicity reduces consumer preference and confidence, decreasing demand at each price level and shifting the demand curve to the left.

questions.question: The five main determinants of demand that shift the demand curve are:
options: Income, tastes, prices of related goods, expectations, number of buyers
Costs, technology, number of sellers, taxes, expectations
questions.explanation: The five main demand shifters are: consumer income, consumer tastes and preferences, prices of related goods (substitutes and complements), consumer expectations, and number of buyers in the market.

questions.question: If a major snowstorm is forecast for tomorrow, today's demand for snow shovels will likely:
questions.explanation: Expectations of future need (due to the snowstorm) increase current demand as people prepare, shifting the demand curve to the right.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand the determinants of demand and can accurately predict how various factors shift demand curves.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basic demand shifters but review the specific effects of income changes, substitute prices, and complement prices.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on the five main demand shifters: income, tastes, prices of related goods, expectations, and number of buyers. Remember that the good's own price causes movement along the curve.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember the key difference: changes in the good's own price cause movement along the demand curve, while changes in other factors shift the entire demand curve.
